text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English
From BBC Learning English
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English,
the show that brings you an interesting topic,
authentic listening practice and six items
of incredibly useful vocabulary.
I'm Dan and I'm Neil.
In this program, we'll be discussing
the lovely topic of lunch
and what our lunch choices say about us.
So Dan,
what are you doing for lunch today?
Ah, Neil, are you asking me to join you?
I'd love to!
Thanks!
There's this great little Vietnamese place
we have to check out.
It's right next to the office if you just...
Ah, actually – I was just asking to… open up today’s topic. Sorry. You see, I’ve brought a sandwich.
speaker: Neil

text: Sorry, you see, I've brought a sandwich.
Oh, a sandwich.
Again.
How dull.
Well, you're not the only one.
A survey from 2012 showed a third of Britain's
eat exactly the same thing for lunch every day.
And yes, it's mostly sandwiches.
I had a carry yesterday.
Well, it's almost lunch time,
so we'd better get on with our question.
Which is,
how long is the average lunch break in the UK?
Is it...
a) An hour and a half
speaker: Dan

text: B, 45 minutes, or C, 25 minutes?
Oh, I wish it was an hour and a half,
Oh, I wish it was an hour and a half, but I’m pretty sure it must be c) 25 minutes
speaker: Neil

text: Well, we'll find out if you're right,
just before lunch.
Well, we’ll find out if you’re right… just before lunch! All this talk of lunch is actually making me feel a bit peckish.
speaker: peckish

text: Peckish.
That's a great word, isn't it?
It's a slang word for being a bit hungry,
feeling peckish, Dan.
I am now.
Now, about you and your sandwiches, Neil.
Two slices of bread with filling might be the most
popular British lunch choice,
but it didn't used to be that way.
Listen to food writer B Wilson,
which adjective does she use to describe sandwiches?
They were what you had in emergency.
They were what you had on a long train journey.
It was a kind of makeshift lunch
when you couldn't get anything better.
So sandwiches had humble origins as makeshift meals.
Makeshift describes something temporary and low quality,
a solution you create when you can't do anything better.
I can't help feel all this is getting a little personal, Dan.
There's a sometimes very practical reason to eat a sandwich.
Like on a train.
On a weekday in the office, though, there's no excuse.
Well, if you worked as hard as I did, Dan,
you'd only have time for a sandwich,
which is just what B Wilson was saying.
We treat lunch time as if it were an emergency.
It says something about our attitude to work and food in the UK.
Next, let's hear from philosopher Julian Bagini
with his view on eating the same thing every day.
And let's teach one more word first,
utilitarian.
It describes something practical and useful,
rather than attractive.
What lunch says about us is that we're still very much stuck
in this kind of quite functional,
you know, efficient utilitarian attitude
of how we should construct our daily lives.
And for all our embrace of this great food culture and everything,
we haven't managed to make that.
And every day thing, it remains something for the special occasions.
So – he thinks we live in a world where we value being efficient – where we have a functional, utilitarian attitude to life.
speaker: utilitarian

text: where we have a functional utilitarian attitude to life.
Exactly.
We're aware of a great food culture.
Exactly, we’re aware of a great food culture, we embrace this culture – but only for special occasions.
speaker: embrace

text: Yes, let's look at that word embrace.
It normally means this.
Let me just, um,
oh, Neil, I didn't know you cared.
Neil just hugged me.
Wrap his arms around me, embraced me.
Just as we can embrace physical things in people,
we can also embrace ideas.
Here's an idea I embrace, Neil.
We should all embrace new foods,
broaden our horizons.
To broaden our horizons means 'to open our minds and experience new things'.
speaker: broaden our horizons

text: and experience new things.
Let me broaden your horizons right now.
Experts from Cornell University say it leads
to better team spirit if colleagues eat together.
Okay, I get the picture.
I should ditch my sandwich and eat with you
in the name of team spirit.
That is getting on well with team members
having a feeling of belonging.
Finally.
Finally. Vietnamese?
speaker: Dan

text: Oh yes, but not before you tell me the answer to today’s question. How long do Brits take for lunch?
speaker: Neil

text: How long do Brits take for lunch?
Well, the answer was C, 25 minutes.
That comes from a survey done by the BBC this year
to find out about our modern dining habits.
c) 25 minutes
speaker: Dan

text: It's a crying shame, Dan.
But before we have lunch ourselves,
let's run over the vocabulary one more time.
First up, we had Peckish.
It means hungry, just a little hungry.
I'm feeling rather peckish at the moment.
I think I’ve gone beyond peckish, Dan. Roll on lunch. Next?
speaker: peckish

text: Roll on lunch.
Next, we had MakeShift,
which describes a temporary or low-quality solution.
For example, last week my team's goalkeeper was sick,
so I had to replace him as a MakeShift goalie.
Or another example,
Or, another example – when I was a student I used the steel bin in my room as a makeshift drum.
speaker: makeshift

text: as a MakeShift drum.
I'm sure the neighbours loved that.
Mm-hmm.
Now, what about this word utilitarian?
In the context we used, it means simple and functional
rather than beautiful.
Do you think it would be fair to describe your polo shirt as utilitarian?
speaker: utilitarian

text: as utilitarian?
I prefer classic and timeless. Please.
speaker: Dan

text: Please.
Well, enough of all this banter.
But enough of all this banter. You know, I believe we should all just get along.
speaker: Neil

text: Oh, are you going to hug me again? To embrace me?
speaker: embrace

text: To embrace me, not this time,
let's stick with the metaphorical meaning
to accept a new belief or idea.
For example, I wasn’t sure about the new website design, but now I fully embrace it.
speaker: embrace

text: but now I fully embrace it.
Very nice.
Very nice. And I embrace your suggestion that colleagues should eat together.
speaker: embrace

text: It looks like you’ve broadened your horizons.
speaker: broadened your horizons

text: Well, when I taught English in Spain, Japan, Poland,
and the Czech Republic, it really broadened my horizons
and taught me about new ways of life.
How about you?
Yes, they say travel broadens the mind.
It's certainly broadened my horizons, too.
Even better.
Why don't we go traveling together
with the whole learning English team?
Yeah, that would be wonderful for team spirit,
the good feeling of being together.
Maybe to Cambodia?
It certainly would.
That's the end of today's six minute English.
Please join us again soon after our delicious lunch.
And we're on social media too.
And we are on social media too. Make sure to visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages.
speaker: Dan

text: and YouTube pages.
Goodbye.
Bye!
speaker: Both

text: Six minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com.
